title: When is sated devourer getting the nerf that it deserves?
body: It's ridiculous how such a disgusting item can be completed by the 20 minute mark or pre-20 looking at {{champion:102}} . It's way too easy, either nerf a jungler's clear speed or increase the stacks needed.

Don't worry... RIot has already made the plans. It's been confirmed.

I'm _not_ a jungle expert, so I'm asking this more to stay informed and in the loop than to offer a specific challenge/suggestion, but what is the nerf that it deserves?

Is it too easy to finish?
Is it too good before finished?
Should we be looking at a few specific outlier junglers?
Is it just too strong once finished?
Is there something else?

As you see it, what is the specific cost the game is paying on account of it being in its current state? It seems like there are a lot of different approaches one could take toward scaling it back a notch. If we were to do so, we'd want to make sure we did the right one.

Again, I'm not a jungle expert and I don't personally monitor items' performance, but I am interested in hearing all your opinions.

1. **Too strong once finished.**
2. Dragon control becomes a MUCH higher balance point of the game, allowing fast completion of item.
3. on a large number of champions (the aa based junglers), it can be as strong ON-PURCHASE as the Warrior enchant, which does not scale. (some have claimed the Warrior enchant needs a buff.)
---
in short, it starts strong, and **rewards snowballing too much**.

I feel as if "Sated Devourer" just needs to be removed in general it was fine as it was before but now junglers only need to be tanky with a trinity force or black cleaver and a challenger's smite to litterally out damage the rest of your team and siege towers so quickly that you honestly cant do much about it.

IMO the problem with Sated Devourer is very simple

Doubling on-hit effects is simply **too strong** on some champions, to the point they straight up break the game. Yi and Shyvana with their on-hits, and Kayle because she can go invulnerable for 3 seconds and able to do too much damage with the item.

I think this specific "power-up" portion should be reworked to something useful, but not as strong. It synergizes too well not only with some champion kits that are incredibly unfun to play against, such as the previously mentioned Yi, Shyvana and Kayle, but also with {{item:3153}} and, honestly, the item by itself is already strong without any other interactions.

It's a creative mechanic and I applaud Riot's attempt to make it an useful item and bring life back to many forgotten junglers, and get rid of infinite scaling Feral Flare-style items. However the interaction with on-hits is simply too strong, the item alone will give you 180 magic damage every 2 autoattacks, so an average of 90 on hit-magic damage - which is already HUGE. Couple that with the fact that the item is, what, nearly 200% gold efficient without even counting its passive which is its main strength by far... and you've got a problem.


**My suggestion?** REMOVE the on-hit doubling, EXCEPT on its own effect, so you'll still get an average 90 magic damage on-hit. And grant it another minor bonus on every second autoattack, such as +15% movespeed for 1 second for sticking power, and/or a small amount of true damage (10% total AD?). I think this would keep the damage from going completely out of control with %health on-hits which is mostly what is abused right now majorly by Shyvana and consistently by anyone building BORK. Devourer should have its role clarified as a mixed damage powerhouse for champions that dive backlines, they definitely shouldn't be melting squishies INSTANTLY and tanks very quickly. I think Devourer's weakness should specifically be health stacking since it has incredible mixed damage, and that's why I suggest a SMALL amount of true damage, but also sticking power for champions that need it.

Its too strrong once finished, it makes champions like kayle outright broken. This promotes a toxic gameplay. Either dominate your opponent before 20-25 or lose the game. Previous ff was just like this, and this item iseven worse with the sated passive which works on already good champs and makes them broken.

I'm not an expert either, but I have been a jungle main since season 2.  My personal opinion is that Sated Devourer is certainly not disgusting.  'Disgusting' would fit Feral Flare or the Pre-season version of Devourer, not Sated Devourer.  But I think the item does deserve a tweak or two.

> [{quoted}](name=RiotRepertoir,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=sKZ1BtYl,comment-id=0025,timestamp=2015-08-11T17:29:18.082+0000)

> Is it too good before finished?

> As you see it, what is the specific cost the game is paying on account of it being in its current state? It seems like there are a lot of different approaches one could take toward scaling it back a notch. If we were to do so, we'd want to make sure we did the right one.

- In my opinion it is not too easy to finish.  If you manage to get off a couple successful early ganks, it's very easy to finish.  But then, so are most jungle items.  The issue comes in with snowballing.  Devourer kind of directly counters cinderhulk, and to an extent even Warrior, because Sated snowballs so much harder than the other two, while being just as easy to complete as those two.  The balance here is that the common champions that build it (like Nocturne, Yi, Shyvana) usually have awful ganks early.  So if you manage to pull off a gank early, when you're weak at doing so, you then get to snowball and skip right past your weaknesses.


- Sated isn't really all that good before it's finished.  It's about even with the others, it's just that champs like Shyv and Yi synergize really well with attack speed.  But until it's sated, they can't really do much until they get another item, usually a BotRK, or just work to get it sated.


- I think it is a few specific junglers that really can use Devourer at all and be good with it.  I've seen it on all kinds of junglers, but most builds fall flat on those champions, outside of maybe four or five.  While things like Devourer Kayle are good if you leave them alone, literally anything is good if you leave it alone.  I played in a game where a Devourer Taric jungle got to the point where he could solo baron.  And did solo baron.  In my opinion, that doesn't mean Devourer is too strong of an item, it's that you somehow lost the game so hard that the Devourer Taric jungle got to build 5 items.  That's a case by case basis on how hard you lose a game, not how good the item is.


- My feel is that the item is a bit too strong once it's finished.  As in, fully sated.  Because with that last stack, you go from having a decent amount of power, to being super incredibly powerful.  It's an instant spike of power which can't be matched by any other item in the game, really, at least in terms of the types of champions that use it.  Personally I would like to see it if the item scaled a bit better to its final strength as you stacked it, then it wouldn't be such a shock to see the enemy Yi, who up until now didn't do much damage last time you saw him, but now he is three-shotting you because of his passive and the double hits on Sated.

Sated Devourer falls into the same Feast or Famine issue that was supposed to be combatted.  If you manage to buy it early, and you manage to stack it, that moment you complete it, you are usually the most powerful champion in the game and can duel anyone.  If you buy it late, and can't manage to get stacks due to your team being behind, it feels awful because the item itself only gives attack speed and that isn't very useful when you're trying to claim your own jungle back from the enemy.  It isn't even an issue of the stacks capping at 30.  

If you are behind the other devourer jungler and they hit 30 first, they will get their power spike first, and you are severely limited in your options of finishing your stacking.  And even if you do manage to finish your stacks?  It doesn't really matter, because you're going to be behind anyway due to how snowbally the item is, and the fact that the enemy should've taken advantage of the huge boost in power than getting that last stack gives them, so now they will have a gold/item/map advantage.

And I think that's the main issue with the item, being snowbally and being completely feast or famine.  It's very rare that there is a devourer jungler in a game who is just kind of okay.  Usually they get super powerful and are a force to be reckoned with, or they can't finish stacks and are basically dead weight to the team.  Very little in-between.  I do not believe nerfing Devourer is the best option, but I think tweaks that make the power curve more of an actual curve rather than a sudden cliff at the 30th stack may help smooth out how feast or famine the item is.  Perhaps damage per auto attack until it transforms into the Sated phantom attacks, or something, I'm not entirely sure.


Edit: Another note is that Devourer usually makes your jungler fall off really hard, as you're usually dedicated to going at least two on hit items (including Devourer) to actually get any real benefit from it.  So after a certain point in the game, where you can't instantly burst people down, you have the late-game assassin/late-game Yi effect, where as soon as you're caught by any CC, you get deleted.  That makes it so that Devourer junglers don't really 'turn on' until 18-22 minutes into the game, and then they 'turn off' around 35-40 minutes into the game.  They have that 20 minute window to win or else they end up feeling pretty lackluster, both before and after that window.  There are certain exceptions to this, just as with every other general rule.

I am of the opinion that, contrary to what many players seem to think, devourer is not actually overpowered. Here's why:

Devourer can be easily delayed by constant pressure on the enemy jungle. It takes a dedication by each of the lanes to support your own jungler on invades, but you can ward jungle paths and gank these junglers in the middle of their routes. Successful ganks can turn a game into a 4v5. You just have to play out the weakness of the item. One of the main take-aways from watching the pros play League of Legends is that they are constantly looking for ways to disrupt the enemy jungler and it really makes devourer's weakness show when they are able to consistently interrupt a devourer jungler.

If any changes should be made to devourer, its that the attack speed you gain from the item should scale with the number of devourer stacks up to the current value at sated transformation.  This might be overkill though, because the item offers nothing but attack speed until devourer is finished.
It's a poorly designed item. Riot needs to give up entirely on the damage on-hit jungle item and make a completely new item for attack speed junglers that has a different design.

3. Sated Devourer added - more broken than the two previous versions combined, yet to be nerfed.

This is more than enough to walk past me and deliver that damage with FAR less mitigation to any of my carries, given her movement speed buff and point and click damage + slow, there's nothing anyone can do but try to peel, as stated, I end up 40% HP down before the fight even starts, and I can only lock her up for pretty much exactly the duration of her ultimate with my maxed E.

Sated Devourer isn't as big of an issue as people think, it's a definitive power spike for on hit champs who usually have to wait another ten to fifteen minutes before they start becoming an issue, but this is inherent in the class that is melee carry.  Either their early game is so blah and weak that you're either power farming or getting farmed until the 20-30 minute mark, or something comes along and suddenly that near broken level of power you bring to bear late game hits early and you're wrecking house.

Sated Devourer is an attempt to make the on hit/melee carries viable and unlike Feral Flare is MUCH closer to accomplishing this.  Honestly some tweaking is all that's really necessary.  It doesn't have the on hit heal which is what made FF so dangerous and without the ability to abuse Challenging Smite we're closer than ever to seeing a decent item for on hit junglers and melee carries.
